name: Titanium.UI.AlertDialog
summary: An alert dialog is a modal view that includes an optional title, a message and buttons, positioned in the middle of the display.

events.name: click
events.summary: Fired when a button in the dialog is clicked.
events.description:
There is a subtle difference between singletap and click events.

A singletap event is generated when the user taps the screen briefly without moving their finger. This gesture will also generate a click event.

However, a click event can also be generated when the user touches, moves their finger, and then removes it from the screen.

On Android, a click event can also be generated by a trackball click.

properties.name: cancel
properties.summary:
Boolean type on Android; Number on iOS.

On Android, indicates whether the cancel button was clicked, in which
case returns `true`.

On iOS, the value of the [cancel](Titanium.UI.AlertDialog.cancel) property is
returned, if defined, or `-1` otherwise. Also note that the cancel button may not be
used on the iPad, because iOS will internally decide whether or not to show it in
the current context (e.g. in a popover).

See the `Three-button Alert Dialog` example for a cross-platform workaround for this
parity issue.

properties.name: index
properties.summary: Index of the button that was clicked.

properties.name: login
properties.summary:
Value of login field if dialog `style` property is defined as
<Titanium.UI.iOS.AlertDialogStyle.LOGIN_AND_PASSWORD_INPUT>.

properties.name: password
properties.summary:
Value of password field if dialog `style` property is defined as
<Titanium.UI.iOS.AlertDialogStyle.LOGIN_AND_PASSWORD_INPUT>.

properties.name: text
properties.summary:
Value of text field if dialog `style` property is defined as
<Titanium.UI.iOS.AlertDialogStyle.PLAIN_TEXT_INPUT> or
<Titanium.UI.iOS.AlertDialogStyle.SECURE_TEXT_INPUT>.

properties.name: bubbles
properties.summary: True if the event will try to bubble up if possible.

properties.name: cancelBubble
properties.summary: Set to true to stop the event from bubbling.

properties.name: source
properties.summary: Source object that fired the event.

properties.name: type
properties.summary: Name of the event fired.

properties.name: androidView
properties.summary: View to load inside the message area, to create a custom layout.
properties.description:
In an Alloy application you can specify this property with either an <AndroidView/> or <View/> element inside the <AlertDialog/> element, for example:

<Alloy>
    <AlertDialog onClick="doClick" title="Delete"
        message="Would you like to delete the file?" cancel="1">

        <!--  Add View or AndroidView for the androidView property  -->
        <View platform="android">
            <Label color="red" text="Warning!  This change is permanent and you cannot undo it!" />
        </View>

        <ButtonNames>
            <ButtonName>Confirm</ButtonName>
            <ButtonName>Cancel</ButtonName>
        </ButtonNames>
    </AlertDialog>
</Alloy>

properties.name: buttonClickRequired
properties.summary: Setting this to true requires the end-user to click a dialog button to close the dialog.
properties.description: Set to true to prevent the dialog from being dismissed via back navigation or tapping outside of the dialog. This requires the end-user to click on one of the dialog buttons provided by property buttonNames. Note that if the dialog does not have any buttons, then the dialog can only be closed programmatically via the hide() method.

properties.name: buttonNames
properties.summary: Name of each button to create.
properties.description:
On iOS, a button will automatically be created if none are explicitly defined, because without it users would be unable to dismiss the dialog. Conversely, a dialog with no buttons may be created on Android, as the hardware back button may be used instead.

A maximum of 3 buttons is supported on Android.

Alloy applications can specify this property with a <ButtonNames> element containing one or more <ButtonName> elements (see example).

<Alloy>
    <AlertDialog id="dialog" onClick="doClick" title="Decide!" message="Do you really want to do that?" cancel="1">
        <ButtonNames>
            <ButtonName>Confirm</ButtonName>
            <ButtonName>Cancel</ButtonName>
            <ButtonName>Help</ButtonName>
        </ButtonNames>
    </AlertDialog>
</Alloy>

properties.name: cancel
properties.summary: Index to define the cancel button.
properties.description: On iOS, set to -1 to disable the cancel option.

properties.name: canceledOnTouchOutside
properties.summary: When this is set to true, the dialog is canceled when touched outside the window's bounds.

properties.name: destructive
properties.summary: Index to define the destructive button.
properties.description: Setting this property to -1 disables this option.

properties.name: hintText
properties.summary: Hint text of the text field inside the dialog.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as PLAIN_TEXT_INPUT or SECURE_TEXT_INPUT.

properties.name: hinttextid
properties.summary: Key identifying a string from the locale file to use for the hintText property.
properties.description: Only one of hintText or hinttextid should be specified.

properties.name: keyboardAppearance
properties.summary: Keyboard appearance to be displayed when the text field inside the dialog is focused.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as PLAIN_TEXT_INPUT or SECURE_TEXT_INPUT.

properties.name: keyboardType
properties.summary: Keyboard type to display when this text field inside the dialog is focused.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as PLAIN_TEXT_INPUT or SECURE_TEXT_INPUT.

properties.name: loginHintText
properties.summary: Hint text of the login text field inside the dialog.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as LOGIN_AND_PASSWORD_INPUT.

properties.name: loginhinttextid
properties.summary: Key identifying a string from the locale file to use for the loginHintText property.
properties.description: Only one of loginHintText or loginhinttextid should be specified.

properties.name: loginKeyboardType
properties.summary: Keyboard type to display when this text field inside the dialog is focused.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as LOGIN_AND_PASSWORD_INPUT.

properties.name: loginPlaceholder
properties.summary: Placeholder of the login text field inside the dialog.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as LOGIN_AND_PASSWORD_INPUT.

properties.name: loginReturnKeyType
properties.summary: Specifies the text to display on the keyboard Return key when this field is focused.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as LOGIN_AND_PASSWORD_INPUT.

properties.name: loginValue
properties.summary: Value of the login text field inside the dialog.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as LOGIN_AND_PASSWORD_INPUT.

properties.name: message
properties.summary: Dialog message.

properties.name: messageid
properties.summary: Key identifying a string in the locale file to use for the message text.

properties.name: ok
properties.summary: Text for the OK button.
properties.description: This property is useful when only one button is required, as it negates the need to define the buttonNames property. If buttonNames is defined, this property is ignored.

properties.name: okid
properties.summary: Key identifying a string in the locale file to use for the ok text.
properties.description: If buttonNames is defined, this property is ignored.

properties.name: passwordHintText
properties.summary: Hint text of the password text field inside the dialog.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as LOGIN_AND_PASSWORD_INPUT.

properties.name: passwordhinttextid
properties.summary: Key identifying a string from the locale file to use for the passwordHintText property.
properties.description: Only one of passwordHintText or hinttextid should be specified.

properties.name: passwordKeyboardType
properties.summary: Keyboard type to display when this text field inside the dialog is focused.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as LOGIN_AND_PASSWORD_INPUT.

properties.name: passwordPlaceholder
properties.summary: Placeholder of the password text field inside the dialog.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as LOGIN_AND_PASSWORD_INPUT.

properties.name: passwordReturnKeyType
properties.summary: Specifies the text to display on the keyboard Return key when this field is focused.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as LOGIN_AND_PASSWORD_INPUT.

properties.name: passwordValue
properties.summary: Value of the password text field inside the dialog.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as LOGIN_AND_PASSWORD_INPUT.

properties.name: persistent
properties.summary: Boolean value indicating if the alert dialog should only be cancelled by user gesture or by hide method.
properties.description: This property is useful to ensure that the alert dialog will not be ignored by the user when the application is paused/suspended.
properties.default: false on iOS, true on Android

properties.name: placeholder
properties.summary: Placeholder of the text field inside the dialog.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as PLAIN_TEXT_INPUT or SECURE_TEXT_INPUT.

properties.name: preferred
properties.summary: Index to define the preferred button.
properties.description:
When you specify a preferred action, the alert dialog highlights the text of that action to give it emphasis. (If the alert also contains a cancel button, the preferred action receives the highlighting instead of the cancel button.) If the iOS device is connected to a physical keyboard, pressing the Return key triggers the preferred action.

Note that this property is only available on iOS 9 or above.

properties.name: returnKeyType
properties.summary: Specifies the text to display on the keyboard Return key when this field is focused.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as PLAIN_TEXT_INPUT or SECURE_TEXT_INPUT.

properties.name: style
properties.summary: The style for the alert dialog.
properties.description: Style of the alert dialog, specified using one of the constants from Titanium.UI.iOS.AlertDialogStyle. Using styles other than default one can break your dialog layout if more than two buttons used. All styles can handle up to two buttons comfortably, except for default style can handle up to six buttons when title and message is empty or not given. Note that this property is only available on iOS SDK 5 or above.

properties.name: tintColor
properties.summary: The tint-color of the dialog.
properties.description: This property is a direct correspondant of the tintColor property of UIView on iOS. For a dialog, it will tint the color of it's buttons.

properties.name: title
properties.summary: Title of the dialog.
properties.description: If not set, a dialog with no title bar will be created.

properties.name: titleid
properties.summary: Key identifying a string in the locale file to use for the title text.

properties.name: value
properties.summary: Value of the text field inside the dialog.
properties.description: Note that this property is only available if dialog style property is defined as PLAIN_TEXT_INPUT or SECURE_TEXT_INPUT.
